GWAScopeR 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Generate a Manhattan Plot for GWAS Data

    manhattan_plot.Rd

    This function generates a Manhattan plot for visualizing the results of a Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS). The plot displays the -log10 of the p-values for each SNP, with horizontal threshold lines indicating significance levels. Vertical lines can be added to mark the top Quantitative Trait Nucleotides (QTNs) or user-provided QTN positions.

    manhattan_plot(map_data, pval_vector = NULL, gwas_data = NULL,
                threshold_type = c("fixed"), alpha = 0.01,
                show_threshold_labels = TRUE, num_qtns = 10,
                user_qtn_positions = NULL)

    Arguments

    map_data

    A data frame containing SNP mapping information with columns `SNP`, `Chromosome`, and `Position`. The rows correspond to individual SNPs.

    pval_vector

    A numeric vector of p-values corresponding to the SNPs in `map_data`. The length of `pval_vector` must match the number of rows in `map_data`. Default is `NULL`.

    gwas_data

    A data frame containing GWAS results, including a column with SNP identifiers and p-values. If provided, this will be used instead of `pval_vector`. The column name for p-values should be `P_Value`. Default is `NULL`.

    threshold_type

    A character vector specifying the type of threshold to use for significance lines. Available options: "fixed", "bonferroni", "inflation", "fdr". Default is `c("fixed")`.

    alpha

    A numeric value representing the significance threshold for the p-values. Default is `0.01`.

    show_threshold_labels

    A logical value indicating whether threshold labels should be shown on the plot. Default is `TRUE`.

    num_qtns

    A numeric value indicating the number of top Quantitative Trait Nucleotides (QTNs) to highlight on the plot. Default is `10`.

    user_qtn_positions

    A numeric vector of user-defined QTN positions to highlight on the plot. Default is `NULL`.

    Details

    This function generates a Manhattan plot where the x-axis represents the SNPs along the chromosomes, and the y-axis represents the -log10 of the p-values. The function allows you to specify multiple threshold types to display significance lines, including Bonferroni correction, genomic inflation, false discovery rate (FDR), and a fixed alpha value. The plot can also highlight the top SNPs based on their p-values or user-defined positions.

    Value

    A `ggplot2` object representing the Manhattan plot.

    References

    Author

    Michelle Marcano-Delgado

    Note

    See also

    varPCs, prcomp, p.adjust, qchisq

    Examples

      # Example 1: Generate Manhattan plot with p-values and GWAS data
  manhattan_plot(map_data, pval_vector = pval_vector, threshold_type = c("fixed", "bonferroni"), alpha = 0.01)
#> Error in manhattan_plot(map_data, pval_vector = pval_vector, threshold_type = c("fixed",     "bonferroni"), alpha = 0.01): object 'pval_vector' not found

  # Example 2: Generate Manhattan plot with custom top QTN positions
  manhattan_plot(map_data, gwas_data = gwas_data, num_qtns = 5, user_qtn_positions = c(100, 200, 300))
#> Error in manhattan_plot(map_data, gwas_data = gwas_data, num_qtns = 5,     user_qtn_positions = c(100, 200, 300)): object 'gwas_data' not found
